  I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Comprehensive  Socioeconomic  Urban 
Development Project in Viet Tri, Hung Yen, and Dong Dang.1 
 
2. 
The  project  will  construct  and  upgrade  urban  infrastructure  and  strengthen  local 
governments’  urban  management  capacities  in  the  project  cities  of  Viet  Tri,  Hung  Yen,  and 
Dong Dang. It is expected that these cities will become economic centers in northern Viet Nam 
to complement Ha Noi.2  
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Regional  economic  corridor.  The  North–South  Economic  Corridor  (NSEC),  which 
connects Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) countries and the southeastern People’s Republic 
of  China  (PRC),  is  a  dynamic  area  of  development.  The  eastern  branch  of  the  NSEC, 
connecting  Kunming  (Yunnan  Province,  PRC)  and  Nanning  (Guangxi  Zhuang  Autonomous 
Region,  PRC)  to  Ha  Noi  and  northern  Viet  Nam,  is  experiencing  rapid  growth  arising  from 
foreign direct investments, cross-border trade, and flows of goods and people. Increased traffic 
and  trade  along  the  NSEC  has  resulted  in  tremendous  development  pressures  on  urban  areas 
along the corridor. The transformation of the NSEC into a full-fledged economic corridor requires 
that these urban areas can function as nodes of economic activity and growth centers, linking their 
hinterlands and the outlying region. Local economic development in corridor cities will benefit the 
NSEC and vice versa. However, the sprawl of settlements along the NSEC is largely uncontrolled, 
leading to additional infrastructure costs and degraded environmental conditions.  
 
Secondary  cities.  The  metropolitan  areas  that  receive  large  inflows  of  migrants  are 
4. 
becoming  more  congested,  and  are  experiencing  increasingly  serious  social  and  environmental 
problems.  At  the  same  time,  secondary  cities  are  stagnating.  If  the  neglect  of  secondary  city 
development  continues,  the  resulting  spatial  and  economic  disparities  will  further  constrain  not 
only urban development, but also social stability and Viet Nam’s overall economic development. In 
line with the government decentralization policy, targeted infrastructure investments in secondary 
cities  will  help  attract  or  retain  residents,  possibly  reducing  migration  to  the  large  metropolitan 
cities.  The  diversion  away  from these  metropolitan  areas  and  the  potential  inducement  to foster 
growth in secondary cities would result in more balanced regional development. 
 
5. 
Urban issues. The main challenges facing corridor cities as well as secondary cities arise 
from  lack  of  urban  infrastructure  investments  and  the  limited  ability  of  local  governments  to 
provide reliable and affordable urban services. Absence of links between the local socioeconomic 
development  plan,  spatial  plan,  and  master  plans  for  urban  subsectors  is  the  major  challenge 
facing  urban  development  and  management.  Inability  to  recover  cost  for  municipal  service 
provision causes poor operation and maintenance of urban infrastructure. This results in missing 
links  in  the  road  network,  obsolete  water  supply  systems  and  high  water  losses,  floods  and 
clogged  drains,  as  well  as  uncontrolled  disposal  of  untreated  wastes  that  contaminate  the 
productive capacity of cities, making them less competitive and livable. Lack of infrastructure and 
limited  capacity  to  manage  urban  services  discourage  external  investments  that  are  critical  to 
socioeconomic development and growth. 

                                                
1   The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

 Project cities. Three urban areas were selected as the project cities: Viet Tri in Phu Tho 
6. 
Province,  Hung  Yen  in  Hung  Yen  Province,  and  Dong  Dang  in  Lang  Son  Province.  They  are 
located along the NSEC outside Ha Noi, and classified secondary cities in northern Viet Nam. 
 
Viet Tri. With good potential to become a logistics hub in northern Viet Nam, Viet Tri is the 
7. 
capital  of  Phu  Tho  Province  and  located  about  84  kilometers  (km)  northwest  of  Ha  Noi,  just 
outside  the  administrative  border  of  Greater  Ha  Noi. 3  Viet  Tri  has  sound  access  to  various 
transport  modes.  Three  rivers  (Red  River,  Da  River,  and  Lo  River)  meet  at  Viet  Tri  where  they 
merge  into  Red  River,  which  flows  into  Ha  Noi.  The  city  is  located  along  the  railway  and 
expressway connecting the Noi Bai international airport and Lao Cai, a border city with the PRC. 
The  distance  between  Viet  Tri  and  the  Noi  Bai  international  airport  is  about  50  km.  Strategic 
planning and investments in public infrastructure development are necessary for Viet Tri to grow 
as a regional logistics hub for efficient distribution of goods. 
 
8. 
Hung Yen. Located between Ha Noi and Hai Phong (62 km to Ha Noi and 108 km to Hai 
Phong), Hung Yen is the capital of Hung Yen Province. Within Hung Yen City is an old town with a 
number  of  historical  relics.  In  the  15th–16th  century,  the  city  was  an  important  center  for 
commerce and trade through its river port. The government has started preserving a number of 
old  buildings  that  have  historical  value.  Further  improvements  in  access  and  environmental 
infrastructure  in  the  old  town  are  expected  to  attract  tourists.  Another  potential  area  for 
development  in  Hung  Yen  is  the  university  zone.  Chu  Van  An  University  is  currently  being 
constructed,  while  Transport  University  and  Foreign  Trade  University  are  preparing  to  open 
campuses in Hung Yen. 
 
9. 
Dong  Dang. The Huu Nghi border gate in Dong Dang handles about 70% of freight and 
passenger  transits  between  Viet  Nam  and  the  PRC  along  the  NSEC.  While  total  trade  in  this 
border  gate  was  valued  at  $859  million,  the  volume  of  passengers  was  recorded  at 
710,606 people in 2010. Since 2000, annual growth rose by an average of 18% in trade and 15% 
in passengers. Trade volume in 2020 is expected to rise to about 10.2 million tons, or $2.78 billion 
in  terms  of  value.  Total passenger traffic  is  expected  to  reach  1.4  million  in  the  same  year. It  is 
clear  that  the  existing  capacity  of  the  Huu  Nghi  border  gate  will  not  be  able  to  handle  such 
expected increases in trade and passenger traffic. 
 
Related policies and strategies. The project is in line with Viet Nam’s Socio-Economic 
10. 
Development Plan, 2006–2010, which envisions Viet Nam as an industrialized country by 2020.4 
In the orientation master plan for urban development to 2020, the government aims to develop 
model  cities  and  divert  rural  migration  away  from  the  large  cities  through  the  development  of 
secondary cities and strengthening of rural–urban linkages.5 The project will address the GMS 
strategy to transform transport corridors into full-fledged economic corridors as identified in the 
Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB’s)  regional  cooperation  operations  business  plan  for  the 
GMS.6 ADB’s draft country partnership strategy, 2011–2015 for Viet Nam emphasizes the need 
to  target  infrastructure  investments  in  small  and  medium-sized  cities,  particularly  those  along 
the  GMS  economic  corridors.  The  project  is  consistent  with  the  priorities  set  forth  in  the 
assessment,  strategy,  and  road  map  for  urban  development  in  Viet  Nam.  It  falls  under  two 
priority areas: (i) development of corridor cities and towns to contribute to the transformation of 
GMS  regional  transport  corridors  into  full-fledged  economic  corridors,  and  (ii)   development  of 
secondary cities and towns as regional economic hubs to foster balanced regional development

 and  strengthen  rural–urban  linkage.  The  project  design  is  also  consistent  with  ADB’s 
Sustainable Transport  Initiative, Water  Policy,  and  draft  urban  operational  plan  under  Strategy 
2020.7 
 
Lessons.  Lessons  from  ADB’s  experience  in  urban  development  include  (i) reducing 
11. 
implementation delays by (a) shortening procurement, (b) strengthening the capacity and skills 
of the government project staff, (c) reducing project start-up time, and (d) shortening the time for 
revising  and  finalizing  designs  and  bidding  documents;  (ii)  improving  consultant  quality  by 
combining  international  technical  capacity  with  local  experience;  (iii)  preparing  more  judicious 
covenants;  (iv)  strengthening  risk  analysis;  and  (v)  employing  comprehensive  corporate  and 
business planning as a tool for communicating and agreeing on capacity building.8 The lessons 
were studied during project preparation and  incorporated in the project design. 
 
Special  features. The project has been designed in accordance with the government’s 
12. 
policy  to  decentralize  the  implementation  of  projects  and  programs  funded  by  official 
development  assistance.  The  provincial  and  city  governments  will  be  primarily  responsible  for 
project  planning  and  implementation.  Infrastructure  improvement  in  the  old  town  in  Hung  Yen 
will  complement  the  government’s  efforts  for  historic  building  preservation  and  catalyze 
comprehensive  redevelopment  of  the  old  town.  This  approach  could  be  replicated  in  other 
historic  cities  if  successful.  Upgrading  of  the  Huu  Nghi  border  gate  facilities  will  create  great 
economic  impact  through  increased  trade,  investments,  and  passenger  traffic  between 
Viet Nam and the PRC. The project will contribute not only to the local economy, but also to the 
country’s overall economy. 
 
B. 
 
13. 
The impact will be the development of Viet Tri, Hung Yen, and Dong Dang as economic 
centers  in  northern  Viet  Nam  to  complement  Ha  Noi.  The  outcome  will  be  improved  urban 
infrastructure and municipal services in Viet Tri, Hung Yen, and Dong Dang. 
 
C. 
 
14. 
 

The project will deliver the following outputs in the three project cities. 

Impact and Outcome 

Outputs 

Viet Tri urban roads. The project will construct and improve the western part of 
the city ring road from the northern dike road to the southern dike road, including 
two road sections, which accounts for about one-third of the total city ring road. It 
will also build a new road from the Noi Bai–Lao Cai expressway to the city center. 
The new and improved roads will enhance connections between the Noi Bai–Lao 
Cai  expressway,  Thuy  Van  industrial  zone,  and  city  center,  as  well  as  reduce 
traffic congestion in the central area by diverting the traffic from National Road 2 
to the city ring road. 

Viet Tri solid waste management. The project will provide fleet and equipment 
for collecting solid waste from households and transporting them to the dump site, 
increasing the current collection volume of 120 tons/day to 150 tons/day.

Hung Yen old town infrastructure. The project will upgrade basic infrastructure 
through  improvement  of  narrow  and  unpaved  roads  with  provision  of  water 
supply,  wastewater collection and drainage pipes, and utility ducts for electricity 
and telecommunications. This approach could be replicated in the remaining part 
of the old town and other cities that have historic townscape in Viet Nam. 

Hung  Yen  urban  road. The project will construct approximately 3.3 km road to 
serve  the  proposed  campuses  for  Chu  Van  An  University,  Foreign  Trade 
University, and Transport University, as well as to attract other universities. The 
road  will  also  serve  as  an  access  road  for  the  residential  areas  currently  being 
developed. 

Dong  Dang  Huu  Nghi  border  gate.  This  output  aims  to  improve  handling  of 
immigration and emigration of cross-border passengers, and custom clearance of 
goods for import and export at the Huu Nghi border gate. The project will build (a) 
office  buildings  and 
the  office  buildings;  and 
(b) infrastructure  of  the  Huu  Nghi  border  gate  such  as  roads,  including  the 
Vietnamese  section  of  the  connecting  road  between  the  Vietnamese  and 
Chinese border gates for transportation of goods, drainage, and parking areas.  

footbridges  connecting 

Dong  Dang  drainage  and  flood  protection.  The  project  will  increase  the 
capacity of drainage pipelines currently laid along one side of the roads. Flooding 
is  a  common  occurrence  during  heavy  rainfall,  severely  disrupting  market 
activities. 

Implementation  support,  capacity  development,  and  awareness  building. 
The project will (a) help ensure that project implementation will fully comply with 
ADB’s  policies  and  operational  requirements  in  terms  of  detailed  designs, 
procurement,  construction  supervision,  disbursement,  financial  management, 
and  social  and  environmental  safeguards;  (b)  design  and  conduct  capacity 
development programs in urban planning and management, public infrastructure 
planning and implementation, operation and maintenance, financial management 
and  cost  recovery,  and  environmental  management;  (c)  help  local  communities 
increase  awareness  of  public  health,  environmental  management,  and  traffic 
safety; and (d) assist in analytical studies on specific topics including a long-term 
residential land development plan for Viet Tri, a detailed master plan for the old 
town  in  Hung  Yen,  and  potential  for  public–private  partnership  at  the  Huu  Nghi 
border gate facilities in Dong Dang. 

 
15. 
Hung  Yen  wastewater  treatment  and  network.  The  government  has  also  requested 
the  Government  of  the  Republic  of  Korea  for  a  loan  from  the  Export–Import  Bank  of  Korea 
(KEXIM)  to  provide  (i)  a  wastewater  treatment  plant,  (ii)  three  pumping  stations,  (iii)  a  sewer 
network, and (iv) maintenance machinery and equipment. These activities will be implemented in 
parallel  with  the  project  and  contribute  together  to  the  urban  environmental  improvement  in 
Hung Yen. Safeguard documentation, consultation, and disclosure for the KEXIM-financed output 
will  be  conducted  to  satisfy  both  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  and  the  safeguard 
requirements of KEXIM.

operation and maintenance after project completion are identified for all project outputs.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

 
A. 
 
21. 
The project involves the construction of new urban infrastructure facilities and upgrading 
of those that already exist. The technology for undertaking such works is within the capacity of 
the  local  government  agencies  assigned  to  implement,  operate,  and  maintain  them.  The  civil 
works  implementation  is  focused  on  quality  rather  than  the  quantity  of  coverage.  The  designs 
and  the  operation  and  maintenance  plan  are  prepared  based  on  appropriate  standards  to 
ensure sustainability. 
 
Government  policy  changes  have  been  made  toward  decentralization  to  delegate 
22. 
responsibilities  from  the  government  to  the  provinces  in  planning  and  management  of  local 
budget  and  human  resources,  as  well  as  land  use,  public  service  delivery,  state  enterprise 
business,  and  natural  resource  control.  The  new  Urban  Planning  Law,  2009  stipulates 
decentralization  of  urban  planning  responsibilities  to  include  all  government  administration 
levels  and  to  require  stakeholder  consultation  with  concerned  organizations,  individuals,  and 
communities. A major challenge is the lack of capacity of local authorities to plan and manage 
urban  growth  in  an  integrated  manner,  plan  and  operate  urban  infrastructure  effectively,  and 
deliver  municipal  services  efficiently.  The  project  will  help  strengthen  the  capacities  of  local 
governments, thus supporting the government’s decentralization policy. 
 
B. 
 
23. 
Economic  analysis  was  carried  out  for  all  seven  physical  outputs  because  of  the 
uniqueness  of  each.  In  undertaking  the  cost–benefit  analysis,  a  variety  of  benefit  evaluation 
methods  were  used,  including  (i)  savings  in  vehicle  operating  costs  and  travel  time,  (ii) 
increased  agricultural  productivity,  (iii)  increased  tourism  revenue,  (iv)  increased  border  fee 
revenue  and  reduced  border  clearance  time,  (v)  revenues  from  sale  of  waste,  (vi)  savings  on 
water  provision,  and  (vii)  other  methods.  Given  the  variety  of  the  outputs,  the  expected 
beneficiaries  of  the  overall  project  also  constitute  a  diverse  group.  They  include  road  users, 
farmers,  university  students  and  teachers,  tourism  service  providers,  property  owners,  and 
households.  The  base  case  results  indicate  all  outputs  are  economically  viable  with  an 
estimated economic internal rate of return exceeding the assumed economic opportunity cost of 
capital  of  12%,  with  the  exception  of  one  output  which  was  marginally  below  that  threshold. 
Results ranged from 11.4% to 18.1%, except for the Dong Dang Huu Nghi border gate in which 
the  rate  of  return  was  estimated  to  be  significantly  higher.  Outputs  were  generally  also  viable 
under adverse scenarios in which costs were higher or benefits lower (by 10% or 20%) than the 

Economic and Financial 

7 

 

 8 

 

Governance 

base case. All of the 29 scenarios tested showed an estimated rate of return above 12%, except 
in four cases where the return was between 9.9% and 11.2%. 
 
24. 
Given  that  the  project  is  nonrevenue  generating,  the  financial  analysis  focused  on  the 
implementing  agencies’  financial  capacity  to  meet  the  recurrent  costs  of  operating  and 
maintaining  the  developed  facilities  in  a  sustainable  manner.  The  overall  financial  position  of 
each  implementing  agency  was  projected,  reflecting  the  incremental  recurrent  costs.  The 
projected  financial  positions  confirm  their  financial  capacity  to  cover  the  recurrent  costs  to 
sustain  the  facilities  developed  under  the  project.  Moreover,  considering  the  government’s 
assurance  that  it  will  fund  the  operating  expenditure  and  periodic  maintenance  of  the  project 
facilities,  adequate  budgetary  amount  for  recurrent  costs  for  operation  and  maintenance  is 
reasonably expected. 
 
C. 
 
25. 
The  financial  management  assessments  reveal  no  serious  obstacles  with  the  accounting 
policies  and  procedures  followed  by  the  PPCs  and  CPCs.  Based  on  the  procurement  capacity 
assessments, the executing and implementing agencies are deemed to have sufficient capacity to 
undertake national competitive bidding for civil works packages. However, considering that they do 
not  have  much  experience  in  managing  externally  funded  projects,  the  project  has  incorporated 
capacity  development  programs  for  relevant  staff  in  financial  management,  procurement,  and 
disbursement. 
 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
26. 
with the government and the PPCs of Phu Tho, Hung Yen, and Lang Son. The specific policy 
requirements  and  supplementary  measures  are  described  in  the  project  administration 
manual.14 
 
D. 
 
27. 
Potential  social  impacts  on  communities  within  the  project  areas  have  been  assessed. 
The  social  assessment  indicates  that  the  project  presents  risks  with  respect  to  livelihoods, 
HIV/AIDS  transmission,  human  trafficking,  participation,  and  road  safety.  The  project  also 
presents  social  and  economic  benefits  to  local  communities  in  the  form  of  improved  mobility, 
economic  opportunities,  social  development,  and  improved  local  environments.  A  poverty 
reduction and social strategy was prepared to present mitigation measures needed to address 
social impacts and enhance distribution of benefits resulting from the project. 
 
28. 
The  project  is  categorized  under  effective  gender  mainstreaming.  The  gender  analysis 
concluded that women in the project area are at risk of being disproportionately disadvantaged 
by  the  project  impacts, or  not  realizing  the full  potential  of  project  benefits  and opportunities if 
gender issues are not mainstreamed in project activities. Accordingly, a gender action plan has 
been  prepared  to  (i)  ensure  gender  issues  are  mainstreamed  in  project  planning  and 
implementation,  (ii)  address  specific  impacts  and  risks  that  may  affect  women  differently  or 
disproportionately  compared  to  men,  (iii)  enhance  participation  of  women  in  project  benefits, 
and (iv) build the capacity of the Women’s Union in the project areas to support implementation 
of social development activities of the project.

E. 
 
29. 
The  project  is  classified  under  environment  category  B.  This  means  that  potential 
environmental impacts of project outputs are relatively minor and can be prevented or mitigated. 
An initial environmental examination (IEE) was prepared for each project city. An environmental 
management  plan  (EMP)  is  included  with  each  IEE.  The  IEEs  indicate  that  potential  direct 
environmental  impacts  are  mostly  construction-related  and  thus  short-lived.  Environmental 
impacts  associated  with 
flood  protection, 
infrastructure upgrading in the old town, and Huu Nghi border gate facilities can be prevented or 
mitigated  with  standard  construction  procedures  and  measures.  Similarly,  the  construction  of 
the new wastewater treatment plant in Hung Yen will follow existing construction practices and 
norms, and will be operated following existing government standards and guidelines for treated 
effluent discharge and solid waste management. During project implementation, the EMPs will 
be implemented by the PIUs in conjunction with contractors under the direction of the PIUs. The 
PIUs  have  adequate  capacity  and  experience  and  are  committed  to  manage  environmental 
risks. Furthermore, project implementation support and a capacity development program will be 
provided for the PIUs for implementing the EMPs. 
 
30. 
The  project  is  classified  under  involuntary  resettlement  category  A.  The  project  will 
require  the  acquisition  of  approximately  97  hectares  (ha)  of  land  in  the  three  project  cities, 
comprising  73  ha  in Viet  Tri,  17  ha  in Hung Yen,  and 7  ha  in  Dong Dang. This  will  cause the 
physical and/or economic displacement of an estimated 1,451 households. A resettlement plan 
was prepared for each project city to address resettlement impacts associated with the project’s 
land  acquisition  requirements  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  The 
acquisition of land for the Huu Nghi border gate facilities in Dong Dang commenced prior to the 
project  in accordance  with the government’s  legislation and  practices. The  project  will  need  to 
ensure that the Safeguard Policy Statement is also met with respect to involuntary resettlement 
from  this  site.  A  resettlement  due  diligence  study  was  undertaken  of  the  affected  land  at 
Huu Nghi  border  gate  and  a  corrective  action  plan  was  prepared  to  set  out  supplementary 
actions required to ensure that involuntary resettlement from this location is in compliance with 
the Safeguard Policy Statement. 
 
The  project  is  classified  under  indigenous  peoples  category  B.  The  presence  of  and 
31. 
potential  project  activity  impacts  on  indigenous  peoples  and/or  ethnic  minorities  in  the  project 
areas have been screened. A large proportion of the people in the project area in Dong Dang 
are ethnic minorities who will be affected in a number of ways by the project, while there are no 
ethnic  minorities  in  Viet  Tri  and  Hung  Yen.  In  Dong  Dang,  the  construction  of  the  river 
embankment  for  flood  protection,  as  well  as  Huu  Nghi  border  gate  facilities,  will  require  land 
acquisition and produce displacement. The vendors at Dong Dang market will likely experience 
temporary disruptions to their livelihoods as a result of drainage civil  works. There are risks of 
HIV/AIDS transmission and human trafficking to the local ethnic minority population. The project 
also presents benefits and opportunities to the local population. An ethnic minority development 
plan, in compliance with the Safeguard Policy Statement, has been prepared to fully mitigate the 
risks and impacts caused to ethnic minorities in the project area in Dong Dang and to promote 
their participation and sharing in project benefits. 
 
32. 
In  compliance  with  ADB’s  information  disclosure  and  consultation  requirements,  the 
safeguard documents are posted on ADB’s website. A grievance redress mechanism has been 
developed  and  included  in  the  safeguard  documents  to  facilitate  resolution  of  complaints 
regarding the performance of the project.

33. 
The  key  project  risks  include  (i)  limited  economic  development  in  the  project  cities,  (ii) 
catastrophic climate events (typhoons and flooding), (iii) limited project implementation capacity, 
and (iv) complex project implementation arrangements. The integrated benefits and impacts are 
expected to outweigh the costs. Major risks and mitigation measures are summarized in Table 4 
and described in detail in the risk management plan.15
